text: from tweepy import Stream from tweepy import OAuthHandler from tweepy.streaming import StreamListener import time  ckey= 'haPRShCXzshaQafBmPvFzXZHC' csecret= '6qLmVfKhh75wTVkHaSEBygnKFGttJICcua6dMxvFR1VwywTLUm' atoken= '154580928-aUUT2gF35Sf6ZJKRK0BxpaaAWEqcarUSvEhKjMxS' asecret= '0YiX9zBcCsnP8jQJIz3pNehTAVxMIBlwQiN2td03n0Clg' class listener(StreamListener):     def on_data(self, data):         try:             #print data             tweet = data.split(', "text":"')[1].split('","source')[0]             print tweet              saveThis = str(time.time())+'::'+tweet             saveFile = open('king4.csv','a')             saveFile.write(saveThis)             saveFile.write('\n')             saveFile.close()             return True         except BaseException, e:             print 'failed ondata, ',str(e)             time.sleep(5)                       def on_error(self, status):         print status  auth = OAuthHandler(ckey, csecret) auth.set_access_token(atoken, asecret) twitterStream=Stream(auth, listener()) twitterStream.filter(track=["bus"])    when i use the above code i'm getting as   "failed ondata, list index out of range" can u help me where is the problem?

author: @miscellaneous3547
text: Hey nice video man.. don't know if you know this but rather than parsing raw data, you can use the onstatus method of tweepy which returns a status object containing all the different parts in it..  def on_status(self, status ):         try:             print str(status.id) + status.text + status.created_at             return True                  except BaseException, e:             print 'failed ondata, ',str(e)             sleep(5)          def on_error(self, status):         print status  Hope you get the point

author: @satishchandrad
text: Nice video. We can even use json module to read the attributes we want from "data". Sample code goes this way: import json : :     def on_data(self, data):         try:             jsonData = json.loads(data)             createdAt = jsonData['created_at']             text = jsonData['text']             saveThis = createdAt + " :: " + text             :             saveFile.write(saveThis)  Hope this helps. Once again, great videos :-) Appreciate it !!

author: @sentdex
text: If you know what they are, then you can just simply run a replace function... so lets say \u521f is a smiley, you can just replace("\\u521f",':)') .. or similar. You can also find all instances of unicode by regex... something like r'\\u(.*?) would be a start to finding them, then just remove em... etc.
